review_content: Our experience began with the free airport shuttle. In order to catch the shuttle, we needed to go to the Regal hotel at the airport. It was about an hour long ride from the airport to the Regal Hong Kong Hotel (RHKH). There was one other stop to the Regal Kowloon before we got to the RHKH. We had upgraded to the executive level so check-in was on the 31st floor. The executive level included breakfast, afternoon tea, and evening cocktails (beer, soda, and wine). The breakfast was very good. Dim sum, fried noodles, eggs, bacon, ham, fresh fruit, pastries, congee, toast, fresh oj, tea or coffee. Our room was very nice. Unlike other reviews, it was just right. The bed was a bit hard, but nothing you can't get used to. The shower takes a little time to warm up, but it was…

date: Girlie G wrote a review Nov 2012
review_content: Was a bit apprehensive with all the negative reviews on this hotel. But I was pleasantly surprised to have been treated to a lovely stay. The hotel staffs were very courteous, helpful and friendly. We were given the room at the 24th floor overlooking Victoria Park. Room was immaculately clean and linens were crisp and smelling good. Location was definitely a plus factor. MTR was nearby. Tramstop located just at your doorsteps. Lots of stores and shops around the area. You are met with a wonderful lovely scent as you enter the hotel lobby and it permeates the entire place. Will i stay here again? Yes!

review_content: My wife and got got the executive floor package with a fairly large room by HK standard. Our room had the highest hotel room ceiling we've ever been in. Nice. The bathroom was OK but the way the towel rack was positioned, one had to be an NBA player to reach the towels without going inside the tub. Mirrors were everywhere in the room. There were double/triple images of the TV from all the mirrors. Poor design. The breakfast lounge was fair at best. The afternoon and early cocktails were poor at best. Cheap wines and beer with a couple of dimsums. Checkin was in the executive lounge but took a long time. Room service was fast and ok. Internet was free but for only 1 laptop. When I connected my laptop and phone, I was already billed for the extra connection. Bad, bad, hotel. Our…

Our club floor guests are entitled to complimentary internet for 2 devices, however, additional connections are chargeable. We may consider reviewing and relaxing this standard in the future. We apologize for not having met your expectations in this regard. We hope to be given another opportunity to welcome you back to our legendary hotel in the future. Sincerely, Alexander Haeusler General Manager Regal Hongkong Hotel

date: James C wrote a review Nov 2012
review_content: During our 3 week trip to Hong Kong and China we stayed in 4 hotels altogether, one in China and 3 in Hong Kong. This hotel is by far the worst hotel I have ever had the displeasure of staying at and was by far the worst of our trip. Firstly, as this was a business trip and we had decided on booking this hotel as WiFi was included and the location was good, I was bemused to find out that all of 15 mins were free daily and you would have to pay to extend this. How is this possible in this day and age? Every other hotel I managed to stay at during my stay offered free wifi and was by far cheaper to stay than this place. To top it all off, when we returned back to the U.K. I checked my credit card statement and discovered I had been charged an extra £50 without warning and…
response_title:
Response from RegalHongkongHotel, General Manager at Regal Hongkong Hotel
Responded Nov 22, 2012
response_content: Dear Mr. James, Thank you for staying at the Regal Hongkong Hotel. We regret to learn that you had an unpleasant experience during the recent stay with us. Regarding your comment about the 15 minutes free WiFi, kindly note that this is a short term access for guests to use the internet in public areas of the hotel. If you book through our web site, then you are entitled to free in-room internet. You may check it out from www.regalhotel.com for further details. We have taken note of your comment of the additional charge on your bill. We are preforming a thoughtful investigation into the matter. However, we do not have much information regarding your profile, therefore, it would be much appreciated, if you could contact us under rhk.info@regalhotel.com. date: Rob H wrote a review Nov 2012
review_title: I was enjoying Hong Kong until I had the misfortune of staying here
review_content: FREE Wifi??? Are you sure??? if you class 15 minutes of interrupted access to the slowest connection in HK as Free wifi then yes there is free Internet access. To be fair this is will be the least of your worries staying at this hotel. I've received better service at Travel Lodge and paid less for a drink at the Ritz in London. The front desk staff were some of the worst I've witnessed in 15 years of international business travel, the room was by far the smallest I've ever stayed in and I certainly did not appreciate the wandering eye of the bell boy every time I entered the hotel. I strongly suggest staying at the Metropark instead, it's just around the corner, amazing staff and you will not receive a surprise £120 add on to your bill for no reason whatsoever. Avoid the Regal…

review_content: I wish I had read these reviews before checking in. Travelocity gave it 5 stars. I probanly would have given it 5 stars 15 or 20 years ago. Old hotels don't have to be dowdy and they certainly ought not be dirty; and this place is both. I was only there for a couple of hours before I convinced them it would take a wrecking ball to keep me there. Travelocity was of little or no help getting me out, getting me my money back or even finding me another accommodation. Hotel staff are pleasant and vacant coz they know 50% of the people that check in are going to have some form of complaint; from the condition of the bouncy elevators, to the low lying bed for which you can see the mattress as the sheets don't fit, to the filty, dirty (it owes them nothing) carpet that should have…

review_content: this is a nice reasonable priced hotel, but it needs some serious cleaning, mould in the shower is not acceptable. I did not like the rooftop bar to be closed at 18.00 since one would like to enjoy a drink and a view after a day at the office.

date: Luke M wrote a review Nov 2012
review_content: The Regal is in Causeway Bay and is well located for business and touristy stuff. Less than 5 minutes from MTR and next to tram and numerous buses it is easy to get around. The hotel is clean, quite (hum of traffic but it is HK) and the staff are very friendly. Has a decent gym for a hotel and a lovely rooftop pool to get away from it for a while. Also the size of the rooms (Deluxe) is very impressive - plenty of space if you are staying for a few nights.

review_content: Maybe I was in a different room but they have made massive improvements since my last visit here. Bathroom remained the same, breakfast is the same, though same for me doesnt mean negative. This room has got a better TV and there is a coffee machine that churns out different types of coffee anytime you need it. Location is awesome, and getting to and from the airport with the airport shuttle is magnificent. Internet connection is good, not great.

date: S P wrote a review Nov 2012
review_content: Pros: 1. Causeway Bay Metro Station is short 5 minute walk away. 2. Time Square is a 10 minute walk away. 3. Ding Tai Fung is right next door! I would go back to this hotel for this reason alone. 4. Most of the staff was fluent in English. I had no problem getting directions or answers from them. 5. The staff knew the area pretty well. 6. Room was spacious in terms of HK standards. 7. Internet was fast (but expensive). 8. Established hotel so most cabbies knew where it was. 9. Great location if you want to go shopping. Cons: 1. Breakfast buffet was bland and too expensive for what it offered. McDonalds was 1 block away. 2. Internet was about US$25+ for 24 hours. 3. Interior was a alittle dated. The room was clean and well kept. But starting to see its age. …

review_content: I've been 2..4 times per year in the Regal HK from 1997 to 2007. This hotel was new, the staff fantastic and the price reasonnable. Even the Asia crisis in 1997 and the SRAS in 2003 I still go there. Since 2005, China allow his residents to visit HK. Since there, the atitude regarding to the foreigner changed definitivly. No good price for long stay, no up-grade, service worse and worse. In parallele we know that people from mainland pay 50% less than us. UNFAIR !!

checked in by a very helpful lady named dolphin in the executive floor.Room very good,Excellent breakfast,afternoon tea and cocktails served by andy. good location good for public transport and local markets and shops and resturants

The wifi in lobby only gives you 15min access everyday, with no seating area, so you'll have to stand there to get internet. Staffs were OK, mostly friendly.

review_content: Location is excellent 2 mins away from Causeway bay MTW and door to door with great Din Tai Fung restaurant. Check in fast, they will try (gently) to get a few $$$ more from you by offering you paid upgrades. Roomsa little old but very well kept. Beds super comfortable. LOTS of english TV channels available. Housekeeping responds INSTANTLY to any request. Breakfast is excellent but pricey at 200 HKD. Convenient shuttlebus with 4 routes. Some minor nuisances: - Bathroom facilities a little old Plugs are english type only, but power adapters are available upon request Broadband access (wifi or wired) can be extremely slow at peak hours

review_title: Change of policies and GM for the worse?
review_content: The Regal HongKong Hotel is no longer what it once claimed to be, among the best of Hong Kong hotels as a 5 star hotel. It should be rated as a 4 or maybe even a 3 star hotel at best. The hotel has become extremely cheap with many new policies set to 'nickel and dime' the guests to death. Unless you book through some tour company in mainland China you will probably pay premium rate for the room with not much of anything else. Maybe that explains why the majority of guests are from Mainland China. I've been a very loyal guest since the hotel opened nearly 20 years ago and stayed at the hotel once or twice each year and for 20+ days each time. I used Hong Kong as a hub when traveling to other Asian countries so I would stay a few nights at Regal Hotel, away for a few and then back…

The room i got was filthy, mould all over the bathroom tiles and a damp smell in the room. The staff suggested i pay double the upgrade fee again to have a better room. i showed images of the mould and the Manager at check out told me I should have complained earlier (despite me doing so anyways) The Manager refused to offer any discount. DO NOT STAY IN THIS HOTEL!

review_title: Bad end to a reasonable stay
review_content: This hotel is on the Hong Kong side and is reasonable value for money with that in mind. Rooms are decent without being lavish or extraordinary. The executive floor upgrade is not worth it, the breakfast up there is very small and cannot match the main breakfast room. The evening arrangement with snacks and drinks has a poor selection. The gym is very poor, but the hotel is right next to Victoria Park where you can take a run. Its 1.4 km per lap and its full of people from early morning to late night. When I had to leave the staff in the executive floor reception, thought the minibar bill was on the high side and wanted to check with housekeeping. That made sense, but then it turned into a farce that took 45 minutes, eventhough after 10 minutes I said, "nevermind, just let…

Check in was fast, but only because nobody else was there at my arrival. Otherwise it looked sometimes slighly overcrowded. What is really important to me is..to feel welcomed...and this is the front desk staff job....unfortunately sour and unfriendfly faces and attitude welcomed me each time I need to visit reception. Breakfast is overpriced ( 25 USD) and you have to pay for Wi-Fi 15 USD/day ( i think ) which is absolutely unacceptable.…

review_title: Well located, nice place to stay
review_content: Stayed here for 4 nights. Check in was good on the whole. We had a very helpful young man who looked to be a manager of some sort, who checked us in promptly. However when we got up to the room, the card did not work and thank goodness too, because I realized that I could hear the TV going, and that someone was having a shower in the room! Back downstairs to rectify the problem - the room was indeed occupied and we would have walked in on the poor guest. Same young man, apologizing profusely and clutching complimentary drink vouchers, gave us a new room and upgraded us to one of the club floors. We were very pleased with this. Until we got into the new room, which we found to be very gaudy and a lot smaller than other rooms (hubby stays there frequently) so we downgraded…

review_title: There are Far Better Hotels on the Island- has Become a Mainland -Package-Holiday-Sausage-Machine
review_content: Before I write a review, I read what others have said about the subject hotel, restaurant, attraction, thingy, etc first. Though I will not review unless I have visited a site several times and formed a sufficiently robust opinion before writing, I think it is important for me to also consider the thoughts of others, to make sure my review is reasonable. If I do not agree with the opinion of another reviewer, I will reflect before typing. After all, while I am lucky enough to travel for a living, there are many who will 'seriously' travel perhaps once in their lives, spending hard earned cash on a single experience they hope will fulfill their dreams. I am mindful of this; I would hate to think some retired couple from Manchester had selected a hotel based, in part, on a…

review_content: This year’s visit to Hong Kong confirmed our choice of returning to the Regal Hong Kong Hotel. Having booked direct, an already good price for a Regal executive suite was crowned by the General Manager’s decision to upgrade us to the “Queen” Suite. This was in recognition of being returning guests and staying for three weeks. The Regal floors bring many welcome benefits – complementary “continental “ breakfast with bacon, eggs, sausages, dim-sum and congee – free airport shuttles – evening cocktails and day long snacks. The breakfast croissants were cold but warming on the top of the toaster brought them to life beautifully. The staff of the executive lounge and reception desk on the 31st floor, were both efficient and friendly- a tone set by their indomitable manager, Angela…

The location was nice, next to Victoria park and my room had a good view. But the amenities for a business traveler were rather limited. And the decoration was a bit gaudy, which might mean you can´t use it for meetings. I would look for a better deal in a simpler hotel.

review_content: A step down from the standard of most global chains but I guess this is somewhat reflected in the price. Service is a bit reserved and aloof but not too much of an issue for me. Great pool at the top of the building and the gym is of acceptable standard. My big bug bar was the absence of ironing board and iron in the room. Whilst both were promptly delivered upon request it was completely lost on the staff that there was not a single powerpoint in the room. For a bloke that needs to iron shirts for work this small issue is a bit of a game changer for me. Otherwise, a great location, right in the middle of the action in Causeway Bay.

The position in Causeway Bay might be good for those who need to do business in that region, and is no doubt well sort after during the HK Sevens Rugby week-end, buit generally it is not in the best spot. Breakfast was not spectacular, and the room service menu limited, not to mention the mini bar prices.There need to be a serious upgrade here, or my HK $ will be going elsewhere in the future.

date: Peripatetic Dreams wrote a review Sep 2012
review_content: stayed in regal for 5 nights in Sept. Its a nice hotel with big rooms. located at almost the end of causeway bay street near Victoria Park. You can take the shuttle which runs from the Regal Airport hotel- although it took me 1.5 hrs to reach the hotel because of the distance, traffic and stops at various regal hotels. you need to pre book your seat on the shuttle. the check in was smooth and did not take much time although during other days i saw a long line in the lobby for check in check out. the rooms and bathrooms were clean. the bathroom did not have a handshower which was a bit of a surprise. also i didnt like the mattress that they had. it was a bit too hard and my neck pained each morning! the roads outside can get extremely crowded on weekends with all tourists and…

review_content: Regal Hotel in Causeway bay is a reasonable business hotel. Its nothing great, but for Causeway Bay, it is way better value usually than the other "5 star" hotels in the area. None of them really rate 5 star. Regal is awkward to get to from taxi point of view, and has way too many loud tourists often in the lobby area, but general facilities for business are ok, the Internet has improved a lot, used to be poor, the general restaurant is very average and noisy, the expensive one is so so, and the gym is a bit pokey and stuck away at the end of a hall in B3 level, no windows, but ok equipment. I have tried cheaper...they are all definitely 3 star levels, I have tried more expensive, and they just are no different, so overall the Regal remains pretty good value for money for the…

review_content: I make it a point to check tripadvisor before we book into a particular hotel. The reviews for this hotel were generally good but everybody commented on the long waiting time at the front desk for checking and checkout. We arrived on the 31st August and expected a long wait. But, to our surprise, we were shown our rooms in less than 15 minutes after all formalities. The friendly lady at the front desk was very cordial although I can't quite recollect her name. The other staff are not always smiling though and could don a smile when they recognize hotel guests.. The room was very clean and big enough for HK standards. The outstanding thing was the room was nicely laid out and very inviting. The bed was even more comfortable giving a good nights rest after a hectic days shopping.…

date: Ross W wrote a review Sep 2012
review_title: Tired Hotel - Exec Lounge very disappointing
review_content: Exec floor was a waste of money - lounge poorly run. Wine and appetizers were not good quality. Lounge manager had very poor attitude. She did not think we spoke Cantonese - very naive. They way she addressed her co workers (who are all younger) was appalling. My customer asked for an umbrella sleeve (it was raining hard outside) and she complained that she would have to call housekeeping. Wifi was free in lounge but had to pay in room (unusual for exec floors where you pay more) No reason to stay at this type of hotel any more with all the boutique hotels in HK where service is prompt and professional. Seemed like a mainland chines tourists were in house - poor combo for business travelers! Great location - but that is all this hotel has going for it...........

review_title: A good hotel that can use some bit of updating...
review_content: My company always book me in this hotel whenever I'm in Hong Kong to hold some business meetings and conferences. The hotel is located within Causeway Bay and is close to a ustling shopping district. Notes: - Good location. Near to Times Square (a high-end shopping mall) and lots of boutiques and stores. - Room is clean. Temperature is something I'm not sure I can control though. Seems it's programmed. - Price is reasonable - Good wi-fi connection (it's not free though). - Breakfast and Lunch buffet is just about right. - staff generally accommodating and helpful though during peak hours, you will not see the smiles anymore. - complimentary water bottles - You cannot sit at the lounge area unless you order at the bar. - Rooms may need a bit of updating in terms of interiors.…

response_content: Dear Guest, Thank you very much for your overall positive feedback. Your comments are encouraging and have been shared with our associates. Please let us know your preference upon booking of your reservation or upon check-in at the front desk. We look forward to welcoming you back soon. Sincerely, Alexander Haeusler General Manager Regal Hongkong Hotel

date: Gim Hoe K wrote a review Aug 2012
review_title: Nice Location but So so Service
review_content: It is located at Causeway Bay, which is the shopping paradise in Hong Kong. The hotel was packed with guest from China and when a hotel is packed with China guest, you will need to have extra patient as you juz gotto wait for everything - check in, lift, check out etc etc. When I entered the room after check in, around 3pm, not even 5min, the housekeeper opened the door without knocking the door, and luckily I yet to remove my clothes for shower and she apologized and told me that the room was yet to fully make up. I juz wonder how could the hotel allowed guest to check in when the room is not ready. I was then tried to access the paid internet but failed. I called for help 2x, 1st time the front desk told me they will reset the password but it did not work, 2nd time the front…

review_content: I recently spent a night here with my husband and our 4 year old son. It's a nice hotel - not fantastic, but certainly not lacking compared to the other hotels in Hong Kong. What you get, though is great location. It's close to the MTR, right in the middle of good shopping malls (where you can get basic amenities), plus great little eateries around the area. There are good dessert places for the evenings (mango pudding, mango sago pomelo and ice cream, you name it!) and late night snacks (HK-style fish balls, beef balls in spicy sauce) within walking distance. In the morning, a short walk down the street will get you great HK porridge with deep fried dough sticks (you tiao).

We look forward to welcoming you back to Causeway Bay and our legendary Hotel. Sincerely, Alexander Haeusler General Manager Regal Hongkong Hotel

date: Jasmin M wrote a review Aug 2012
review_content: Nothing to write home about - it says the place is five stars but our stay at the hotel wasn't all that memorable. The best thing about it was that it was close to the station and relatively central. In terms of things to be aware of - the service is hard to comprehend, maybe it is just the way things are done in HK but we were hoping for international quality. We had free shuttle service to and from the airport included in our room rate, yet we were told on arrival to the airport that the service is booked out and it was first in, first served. After a difficult and partially lost in translation conversation to the concierge at the hotel, there was a spot on the bus found for us. When we finally got to our room at the hotel, it turned out to be a smoking room. I was surprised…

review_content: On one hand, we had a very nice room of good size for HK standard (though it certainly wasn't cheap), on the other hand, we also had to fight for check-in and check-out, waiting a long time for not much to do. Then, they did not want to give us a baby bed for our 2 year-old boy and asked 500HK$ a night for a third bed, which I found exxagerated. I strongly suggest their taiwanese-style dim sum restaurant (which is in the building ground floor, but does not belong to the hotel), which offers a good value.

date: ES K wrote a review Aug 2012
review_title: convenient hotel to Times Sq Hong Kong
review_content: i found it to be a very nice hotel. they provided everything i needed. there is free wifi in the lobby. i visited this past july when we were caught in a typhoon rated 8. there was a lot of rain and wind. hotel was still standing. tree on the street next to it fell. hotel was very accomodating in trying to find out the status of our flight at 05:30 am. we we informed that flight was not canceled. since there was no taxi; we took shuttle bus to the airport express. and made it to the airport. plane finally took off after a 2 and half hour delay. all in all i enjoyed my stay at the hotel.

date: Stuart B wrote a review Aug 2012
review_title: amazing experience at Hong Kong with a nice GM Mr Alex and Club Floor Manager Angela
review_content: I enjoyed coming to this hotel, it is my home away from home. Thanks to all the friendly staff in particular Miss Angela Mak! You can even speak freely with the GM inside the elevator, or anywhere else you meet him, and still feel part of the family. Well done guys ! Strongly suggest to book a Club Room or even upgrade frequent viistors to the Club room so they can see they are missing. Suggest even bringing guests to the Club lounge, even though you pay it is still good value and great atmosphere. Looking forward to a wifi upgrade free for guest no.1 and 2 Many Thanks Stuart Ballantyne--CEO Sea Transport Corporation([--])

review_title: Mmmm... not really that good for a 5 star
review_content: Okay, my experience with this hotel was sort of disappointing. 1st of all a LONG queue for checking in, which obviously couldn't be handled by the staff. Which made me wait. Then go to the nearest Starbucks to take a coffee. Then wait again. And so on. Overall it took about 2 hours just to check in. Well... I've seen better. Anyways, the windows in my room overlooked neighboring house and underwear dryer. Ok, no big deal, it's HK and we have curtains. Quite a problem to get a taxi from the hotel, there is always a big queue for that as well. Generally my whole stay was about different queues. Apart from that - it's a decent hotel.

review_title: Only four sun lounges, a lift that takes forever and poor service
review_content: My introduction to this hotel was via a phone call to the Sales and Marketing manager Mr Stephen Tse, he was rude and arrogant and I should have taken warning then that if head of sales could be so rude to a potential customer it wasn’t a good sign for the hotel and its staff. We arrived late at night from a long flight, being in Causeway Bay means it is quite a journey from airport even if you go by MTR and taxi, for a short stay Id definitely stay Kowloon side. Our room was ready and we were surprised at the size for a four star in Hong Kong. We particularly liked the long window seat which was a perfect place to put our suitcases. Nothing else was terribly spectacular about the room , though I was also pleased that we had a separate shower. Everything was clean and in…

review_content: I ended up staying at this property on a work trip to HK recently and was quite happy with my stay here. The hotel is located in Causebay bay and is quite accessible, with lots of shopping & eating options close by. The room was of a good size, given this was HK and quite comfortable as well. The breakfast buffet was adequate and the dinner buffet was quite vast with lots of choices. Food is not great but not bad either. The aesthetics in the coffee shop are a bit, well, flashy. I guess it appeals to the more touristy crowd the hotel seems to attract. However the Italian restaurant on the top floor is quite good and has a great view of the city. I would recommend eating here, if you need to have a meal at the hotel.

review_title: Has enormous potential, but poorly managed....
review_content: We recently had 9 nights on the Club floor. We felt the price was good, however you get what you pay for. The Club Manager (Angela) would scream to her staff in the next room, everything for her was a huge effort. Lucky Andy was there with exceptional service to help make up for the downfall of his superior! The breakfast and afternoon tea on the Club floor was minimal, with no option available to attend the main dining room as an alternative - in fact, they are inflexible on everything. They had a charge for an airport shuttle on our bill in the middle of our stay - the staff do not have the authority to fix this on the spot, so it took some time and phone calls to have it removed. Our room was spacious and clean and we enjoyed the nespresso machine in our room. Our room…

review_content: I wanted something mid range for a 1 night stop over on the way to europe , the regal was up to my expectations for the price range. I booked a room on the business floor ( 32 ) room was fine , of course decorated in a more 90's style asian way, great bed. Some slightly disturbing stains on the lounge chair in the room,,,not sure what they were and can't understand why they would not have cleaned or replaced . it did let the room down a bit. great view and location. One big positive was the nice pool on the roof a little haven away from all the hustle and bustle. I probably would stay here again and if i wasn't so tired from the flight i would have asked to change rooms due to the lounge.

review_title: Excellent family choice for central Hong Kong
review_content: Choose this hotel if you are staying in Hk with a family!! Finding a hotel in Hk where the rooms are large enough or with enough beds to sleep a family of 4 is tricky. We travel to the city a lot and usually struggle to find a hotel for this reason or we have to make compromises and put both children in a single bed or have our youngest sleep with us which makes for a poor night's sleep as he wriggles so much. I wish we had discovered this hotel before. You can request a room with 2 double beds which is prefect. The hotel also has a great roof top pool which the kids loved, has a great location on the edge of Victoria Park and with easy access to shopping and the metro. At check in the staff were extremely helpful. We had arrived early and, although our room was not ready (…

review_title: Poor Service at Check-in Counter but Nice Sized Rooms
review_content: I stayed for almost a week at the Regal Hong Kong Hotel and was put-off by the poor service both checking-in and checking-out. When I checked-in, the staff was more interested in getting me to sign-up for their hotel rewards programs (no thanks) then telling me essential things, like my room number or where breakfast was. Breakfast was included in my rate, but no one gave me any information about it. When the man checking me in apparently finished, he just tossed my key on the counter and walked away. I couldn’t believe it was such rude service. At the end of my trip, no one asked me about my stay. When I asked about a bus to the metro station (a free service that Hong Kong provides to major hotels), the woman gave me the wrong information, saying that the bus that goes to…

review_content: I stayed at the Regal Kowloon on 5/4 and has a excellent experience. Since my meeting the next week is at the island, I decided to try Regal Hong Kong. I am glad to report the Hong Kong property and staff are as good as the one in Kowloon. Room is clean, service is excellent. I have signed up for the Regal reward program and I checked in via a separate seat down area. The young lady at the reward desk was professional and friendly, I do not remember her name but she's definitely care about what she's doing and it shows. I would rate this as a 4-5 stars property and look forward to use them again.

review_content: A friend had described the hotel as 'faded elegance' so I was expecting the worst. However, I was pleasantly surprised - my room was large and quiet and had all the essentials. Room service was fast and efficient and everything worked. The gym in the sub-basement level was functional - just a pity it was in the bowels of the hotel. The lack of any bar area other than the stark and brightly lit lobby was a pity - but didn't ruin my stay. The neighbourhood is good with a good selection of shops and restaurants within a few minutes walk. The roof top pool was quiet on both visits and a nice place to escape for an hour over the weekend. Other than breakfast I didn't eat at the hotel but the restaurants seemed permanently busy drawing a lot of local business - so I assume that…

date: Turtle T wrote a review May 2012
review_content: I travel to Vietnam numerous times a year, and like to stop for a day or two in Hong Kong. Its on my nickel, so I visit the various discount travel sites to find a hotel in the under $125 range. The same five hotels seem to always pop-up: Regal, Hotel Bonaparte, Cosmopolitan, Cosmo and Charterhouse. All are in the Wan Chai/Causeway Bay Area. The Regal is by far the best value of these five. It has a very nice lobby, the rooms are VERY spacious, and the service is exceptional.

review_content: I believe thar Hotel industry is a services industry, although this us needless to say but I have doubt that Regal Hotel understand this. Despite the recent and on-going refurbishment of the hotel the service is rather disappointing. First of all, the lady that helped to check us in showed us with very unpleasant face as seems we are unwelcomed, there was no single gesture, facial expression or even word of welcome. As we arrived early around 1230pm, the lady told us that the check in time is 2pm and we have to come back at 2pm to check in, she gave us a note with hotel room number and informed us that when we're back at 2pm we can just show it to the front desk again to get the room key. So I came back at 2pm sharp and had to queue at the front desk again and passed the note to…

review_content: We stayed 2 nights during April 2012 at the Regal Hong Kong on a stop over in Hong Kong. We were overall pleased with all aspects of this hotel during our stay. We made use of the complimentary shuttle bus (contact the hotel in advance) from the airport which picks you up from the Airport Regal hotel after obtaining tickets from the regal counter in the arrivals hall at the airport. We had booked an executive room (at a great price on an early booking deal online), therefore had our own executive checkin / reception floor with extremely helpful staff who delivered a more personalised level of service (were extremely helpful with sightseeing ideas and directions). Our booking also included each night, complimentary drinks and snacks within the executive lounge and a full buffet…

review_content: Requested for a change of room bec. initial room had dirty carpet (1516). Next room (1806) was a renovated one, a bit modernized. Very spacious with 2 beds w/c you can push together, bigger than a king bed. Beds and pillows were soft. With tub and separate shower plus toiletries. With safe, coffee&tea, desk. Views are of buildings, Victoria Park and harbor. Cleanliness wasn't up to standard. Hairs on both shower and tub. AC was kinda loud. No help from bellboys to get taxi and to load bags into taxi. Convenient location.

review_title: Does what it says on the box
review_content: Stayed fo four days at the Regal Hong Kong wile in town for business. Overall i was happy with the experience I had. The room was ok, it was kept clean and made up in good time daily. I had no problems with reception staff and most of the other people at the hotel. The only place I did have difficulties was the restaurant on the first floor that is used for breakfast. Staff here were not very nice, verging on the rude especially when seeking a signature for the breakfast docket. The gym was good with very few people using it, so it was easy to get on machines. Also it is open 24 hours, useful if your body clock is out of whack. It is well located in Causeway Bay, close to retail options. It is also close to the MTR, as well as on the tram line. So apart from a couple…

Not a lobby type hotel with chairs, couches etc. Fitness center was dirty. My room was quite clean. Meeting rooms were clean and well serviced. Meeting room food was good.
